title: Studies of the northern frontier do not usefully fall into discrete fields of history, and this probably constitutes their advantage. Since shared assumptions amongst the many Indian and European groups that dealt with one another along the frontier were few in number, culture there had to be the product of continuous negotiation; this has forced those who study the frontier into treatments that cross the borders between economic, social, political, and military history.
